elements.content: A Cd mixed-ligand MOF showing ligand-disorder induced breathing behaviour at high temperature and stepwise, selective carbon dioxide adsorption at low temperature† Tayyibah Tahier and Clive L. Oliver 1–121314,1516–2526–2829–3233,34343536373839–4142II4342444545(a) Basic chemical unit of 1 showing the coordination environment around Cd(II). Hydrogen atoms are omitted and only the asymmetric unit is labelled for clarity (excluding the disordered “B” component of the bpe ligand); (i) 1 + x, y, z; (ii) x, y, z − 1. (b) Coordination bilayer of 1 (c) overlay of the 298 K (yellow) and 323 K (green) ASUs on the 104 K (blue) ASU. (d) Overlay of the 373 K (red) and UJOJUY (yellow) ASUs on the 104 K ASU (solvent molecules are excluded).

elements.content: IICommon view points of bilayer in the 104 K (left) and 373 K (right) structures. a) Edge-on view along the bilayer that shows the rectangular channels b) face-on view of the bilayer showing the square lattice motif and c) edge-on view along the 2nd direction of the bilayer showing the hexagonal channels.

elements.content: Fig. 3 Adjacent bilayers (color-coded) in the 104 K (left) and 373 K (right) structures. (a) View down the hexagonal channels showing their entanglement (b) topological simplification of view in (a) where the metal ions and centroids of the nbdc aromatic rings are taken as the nodes (c) edge-on view of the rectangular channels (d) face-on view of the bilayers showing the entanglement of the square lattice motifs.

elements.content: Fig. 4 (a) Packing diagram of 1 at 104 K with the DMF molecules deleted in order to show that the void space is close to the disordered pyridyl rings of the axial bpe ligands. Void space for the (b) bpe(B)-nbdc(E) (c) bpe(A)-nbdc(E) (d) bpe(B)-nbdc(D) and (e) bpe(A)-nbdc(D) disordered states. Hydrogen atoms are omitted for the sake of clarity.
